title: Web Landscape
text: This timeline shows the evolution of the aesthetics of web browsers, reinterpreting the different elements and assembling them as a city.

title: World Wide Map
text: The WorldWideMap timeline shows how the internet has spread in different countries through time. With the help of a dynamic cartogram (a map where the the scale of each region has been proportionally modified) we are able to lose the connection with the real geographical space and perceive the cyberspace instead. In this way the connected people of each country clearly show their presence on the world wide web.
source: The data used in this visualisation comes from WorldBank.org which has comprehensive datasets for the population and the internet access of most countries. The timeline itself display events about how the internet expanded through time, both in term of connecting new regions and welcoming more users. The information about those internet’s milestones have been sourced with Wikipedia.

title: Web Dictionary
text: This timeline presents an overview of the evolution of vocabulary that emerged with the advent of the Internet in 1989. Words are added and crossed to offer a graphic and dynamic presentation of the different words related to the year of their appearance.
source: The words were found mainly on wikipedia, as well as in Nicolas Nova's newsletter. But other sources complete the list such as Urban dictonnary, the Guardian, medium.com & twitter.

title: Web Influencer Identity
text: This timeline shows the visual identity evolution of the main tech companies on the web through their logo.

title: Web Phenomena
text: This timeline gathers different viral events on the web by proposing a graphical exploration passing among others by the buzzs, the memes and the spamms.

title: Hacks.exe
text: This chronologie shows events that forged the history of cybersecurity on the web. Hacker groups are forming, new mysterious computer viruses appear, governments attack each other and, of course, colossal amounts of data are gathered, stolen, lost or destroyed.
source: All the events on this timeline come from these two Wikipedia webpages : List of security hacking incidents and List of data breaches. Events were then classified in categories and snippets of text from the original sources of the Wikipedia pages were added when more information on the event was needed.
